Number of new jobs created 11. Number of new enterprises established

comment.narrative: 1. No Institution to anchor the programme. 2. No Management Mechanism put in place to guide programme implementation 3. No training materials developed to deliver training module 4. No local trainers trained to deliver training 5. No trained business development advisors 6. No entrepreneurs trained 7. No data on entrepreneurs provided with preliminary and customized business development services 8. No data on businesses formalized 9. No data on existing businesses expanded 10. No data on new jobs 11. No data on new enterprises established

2. Conduct programme evaluation 6. 8,000 entrepreneurs to be trained (30% women) 7. 2,000 entrepreneurs to be provided with business development advisory services 8. 300 businesses to be formalized 9. 1,000 businesses to expand and or diversify 10. 20,000 new jobs to be created (30% women) 11. 500 new enterprises to be established

2. Programme evaluation conducted 6. 11,121 entrepreneurs trained (36% women) 7. 1,209 entrepreneurs provided with Business development service (44% women) 8. 400 businesses formalized 9. 1,500 businesses expanded 10. 26,905 new jobs created (44% women) 11. 320 new enterprises established

2. Develop a full fledged programme document for phase II of Entrepreneurship Development Center 6. 10,000 entrepreneurs to be trained (30% women) 7. 300 enterprises to be provided with Business Development Service 8. 100 businesses to be formalized 9. 200 existing enterprises to expand and/or diversify 10. 1,000 new jobs to be created 11. 50 new enterprises to be established

2. Programme document developed and signed with government 6. 13,974 entrepreneurs trained (37% women) 7. 454 enterprises provided with Business development service support (40% women owned enterprises) 8. 120 businesses formalized 9. 220 existing businesses expanded 10. 1,417 new jobs created 11. 45 new enterprises established

capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Ethiopia

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard
2 Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydrometeorological phenomena There are no Standard Operating Procedures SOP for alert communication by NMA to DRMFSS
Current score 83
2 Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure
Current budget low

1 Capacity assessment scorecard score of 139
2 Domestic target financing is 100M Birr per year

40 AWS have been procured One upper air radio sonde equipment has also been procured and is ready for installation A meteorological mobile calibration unit and equipment have been procured and they are already functional Automatic hydrological gauge telemetry equipment has been identified and is ready to procure
Capacity building training sessions for instrument technicians forecasters and support staffs as well as awarenesscreation events for local communities have been held in various parts of the country particularly for all NMA meteorological Branch Directorates staff and meteorological observers

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for early warnings and longterm development plans

1 Percentage of population with access to improved climate information and flood and drought warnings disaggregated by gender
2 Development frameworks eg GTP that integrate climate information in their formulation
3 Sectorspecific EW products and strategies that integrate climate risks

comment.narrative:
1 Use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for making early warnings is currently low for both women and men
Women 6 million
Men 8 million
2 Currently no development frameworks incorporate climate change information
3 Limited number of tailormade and sectorspecific meteorological products Limited publicprivate partnerships and pay for services contracts

1 Percentage increase in the population who has access to improved EWSCI 50 increase for women and 50 increase for men
Women 9 million
Men 12 million
2 At least 2 of the PRSP policy briefs incorporate analyses of risk maps andor climate change projections influencing longterm planning proposals
3 Development of at least one tailored climate product and presentation of a market research plan on how to implement mobile phone based agricultural advisories both supporting targeted weatherclimate service delivery

This part of the project will be executed after all the equipment is installed and capacity building sessions are held for experts and at the community level The execution of activities is planned to start in 2016

comment.narrative: 1. Non existent fully operational Ethiopian Tourism Organization for enhanced coordination and increased contribution of the tourism sector to national development 2. 1.Fully operational Ethiopian Tourism Organization(ETO) equipped with adequate human resource, IT equipment as well as required systems and procedures 2.Tourism Policy Regulatory and institutional capacity strengthened - Endorsed set of policies and strategies that support local investment/Foreign Direct Investment(FDI) on tourism - Comprehensive regulations and guidelines that promote quality in tourism sector
3. Inclusive and sustainable private sector tourism development strengthened. 100 tourism specific businesses gain knowledge on competitive and sustainable tourism

comment.narrative: 1. No regulatory basis to improve and control the quality of rural energy technologies for Ethiopia. 2. Lack of public awareness in rural communities about the benefits of improved energy technologies for lighting and cooking. 3. No lending on Rural Energy Technologies by MFIs; slow disbursement of an available World Bank loan for the sector of USD 40 million (15% disbursement rate as of April 2014) 4. . At least 120 enterprises in Ethiopia are unable to launch improved businesses due to lack of capital and business expertise.

1 -New regulations for enforcement of standards in place. -Over 500 individual stakeholders have been trained in implementation and adherence with the new standards and regulations300,000 Rural Energy Technologies ( RET) items sold directly at roadshows 2.. title.narrative: Restration & Resil of Refugee Commun. GMB

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen resilience of host communities, IDPs, refugees, local govts & institutions to provide basic services and cope with the large influx of refugees.

title.narrative: Capacity Building for Peace Support Training Center

description.narrative: The Capacity Building Project for the Ethiopia, Peace Support Training Center (PSTC)) aims to enhance the technical skills and knowledge of local and international peacekeeping practitioners.
The project will sustain all aspects of peace operation training in Ethiopia and Africa in general. It will also contribute towards successful peace support operations of Africa and the UN.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

This project initiation plan would support the government and other stakeholders to formulate a comprehensive programme on strengthening disaster and climate risk governance capacities at national, regional and district level.
